headline: Raspberry Thumbprint Cookies
description: These pecan thumbprint cookies filled with raspberry jam are buttery and delicious. They remind me of a miniature pie in flavor and looks. They are a delicious cookie any time of the year, but especially perfect for the holiday season.
name: Raspberry Thumbprint Cookies
recipeIngredient: 1 (8 ounce) jar raspberry jam, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

Beat butter, shortening, and brown sugar in a large bowl with an electric mixer until smooth and creamy. Beat in egg yolks and vanilla until incorporated. Add flour 1 cup at a time, mixing briefly after each addition. Mix in salt.

Beat egg whites lightly in a small bowl; transfer pecans to a shallow bowl. Pinch off and roll dough into 1-inch balls. Dip each dough ball in egg white, then roll in pecans to coat. Place cookies on an ungreased baking sheet. Use your thumb to form an indention on the top of each cookie and spoon a small amount of raspberry jam into the hollow.
Bake in the preheated oven until very lightly browned, 10 to 12 minutes.

review.reviewBody: WAY too dry. When I adjusted/increased the cookie quantity in the recipe, apparently the butter did not increase accordingly. I checked the math after trying to diagnose why it was so dry and awful. I also think all butter rather than some shortening would have given it a lot more flavor. Bad recipe all around.
too dry need more butter or crisco

They were really good. Nice soft cookie, without being flat. The nut & raspberry filling complimented each other. I did experiment rolling a batch in coconut & used apricot filling. They were good too but took a couple of extra minutes to brown the coconut. It made a nice mixture for gifting.
Be very careful if you use the adjust feature to make a smaller or larger batch, it turned cups into tablespoons on the flour. Better to do the math yourself.
Instead of raspberry preserves i used candied red and green cherries. They were perfect!

i did put in nutella after baking the cookies. if people watch the amount of flour they use, these cookies are perfect. i did not refrigerate just needed a bit and make my balls using a cookie scoop. these are a keeper. i got 25 cookies, one for the baker.

I loved these cookies! I used roughly the butter/shortening ratio, though probably slightly more butter but overall the same total volume. I found the dough quite firm even without chilling. Both pecans and walnuts worked well—even though I normally don’t really like walnuts. The best jam to use is tart, to balance out the flavours. I liked gooseberry jelly best. I will make these at Christmas because they are more fancy and finicky than my usual cookies.

This is how my family made Raspberry Thumbprints for years. Only differences are all butter with no shortening and we added the jam right when the cookies came out of the oven still warm. If we wanted something different we replaced the jam with a room temp Hershey chocolate kiss (make sure its pressed into the warm cookie right when they come out of the oven since this will slightly melt the chocolate kiss to adhere to the cookie). M
EASY! Great tasting!

Although these cookies are a bit labor intensive, the results are worth it- they’re delicious! I used all butter, instead of part Crisco, and tried peach jam in some of the cookies. We liked them but preferred the raspberry ones. 
All in all, a great cookie, and I’ll definitely make them again!

Used all butter and chilled the dough. Used a Ziploc bag to pipe plum fruit preserves. Turned out perfectly and smelled amazing when I pulled them out of the oven. This is now one of my favs; everyone loves them.
I have made these cookies for years!! The BEST cookies ever!

mmmmm. these are a favorite at christmas time. my mom use to make them when we were kids and my kids grew up on them for the holidays. this receipe is just like hers, i didnt need to tweek a thing its perfect the way it is.
I used cherry jelly and mint jelly and love them both.
I made these using apricot/pineapple jam and followed the recipe exactly. They came out amazing!

This is the recipe my family uses, except we use all butter. Also, 1" is a little big (they do spread). I prefer to bake them for 5 minutes in balls, then pull them out and press them, and put back in the over for 8 or 9 minutes. I always put the jelly in after they're out of the oven, so the jelly doesn't run!

Very good. I've wanted to make these for years but the recipes always seemed too time consuming or difficult. This recipe is easy to follow. I used all butter instead shortening. A few suggestions from other comments really helped keep things simple. Chill the dough before rolling it into balls and also put the jam in a ziplock and cut a corner off to squeeze the jam into the thumbprints. Thank you for sharing and thank you also to all of you who left suggestions/tips in your reviews!
Dry, not sweet and tough.

I used all butter and I used walnuts instead of pecans and ended up putting them in the dough as well as rolling the balls in them. I had my homemade cherry plum jam to substitute for raspberry. I did bake for 15 minutes at 350. My sweetie loved them.
Just like the cookies from my childhood! My daughters loved these cookies as much as I did. The crunchy nuts, buttery cookie, and sweet jam are a perfect combination.
very good! hits the spot! cooked in oven at 350 degrees for 12 mins. made 2 and a half dozen.
I used 1/4 cup maple syrup along with the b.sugar and rolled them in ground almonds. 350 for 15 minutes. Homeade strawberry freezer jam. Delicious!

Really great! Used all butter (no Crisco!) Pecans are best if chopped REALLY fine. Chilling the dough helped. I was making these for a reception so I wanted them small. I made them smaller than 1", then "thumbprinted" them with a wine cork. I also used a raspberry "all fruit" spread (in a ziploc bag with corner cut off for EASY application.) Made 5 dozen. I will definitely make these again!!!
my favorite of all the thumb prints!!
Oven temp is 350. This recipe will make less than 4 dozen regular size cookies. In order to make a bite size cookie, use a nickel size cookie ball.
I used my tart 'World Famous Cranberry Sauce' to fill these and I love them! I baked them at 350 for 12-13 minutes.
These are delicious!!
My son says this was like the reciepe that I lost of my mom's.
